metadata.title: Experimental investigation on non-Newtonian behavior of Al2O3-MWCNT/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant affected by alterations of temperature, concentration and shear rate for engine applications

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Communications in Heat and Mass Transfer
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate / ichmt
Experimental investigation on non-Newtonian behavior of Al2O3-MWCNT/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant affected by alterations of temperature, concentration and shear rate for engine applications
Mohammad Hemmat Esfe a,⁎, Rostam Karimpour b, Ali Akbar Abbasian Arani b, Jalal Shahram c a Department of Mechanical Engineering, Imam Hossein University, Tehran, Iran b Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kashan, Kashan, Iran c Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: m.hemmatesfe@gmail.com (M. Hemm
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.icheatmasstransfer.2017.02.00 0735-1933/© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Available online xxxx
In the present study, rheological behavior of Al2O3-MWCNT (65%–35%)/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant is experimentally evaluated with the aim of facilitating its applications in automotive industry. Aluminum oxide (Al2O3) nanoparticles with the mean diameter of 50 nm along with multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with inner diameter of 3–5 nmand outer diameter of 5–15nmwere used as nano-dispersants. Dynamic viscosity of samples of hybrid nano-lubricant composed out of 0% up to 1% solid volume fractionwasmeasured at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C and shear rates between 666.5 and 10,664 s−1. As a result it was revealed that the hybrid nano-lubricant is a non-Newtonian fluid, also power law index signified shear thinning (pseudoplastic) behavior of the fluid. It was observed that increasing of solid volume fraction aggravates non-Newtonian behavior of the nano-lubricant; on the contrary, temperature increment had the reverse effect. For the purpose of forecasting viscosity of the hybrid nano-lubricant, a new correlation is proposed which is based on temperature and solid volume fraction. R-squared of the correlation outputs is 0.9923, thismeans that the correlation is capable of modeling viscosity behavior of the hybrid nano-lubricant.
© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Nano-lubricant Rheological behavior Power law index New correlation
1. Introduction
Many researches have been conducted over the last decade on nanofluids in order to identify the effects of dispersed nanoparticles on base fluid characteristics as well as improving heat transfer properties of fluids being used in engineering applications. Finding of the optimum condition of a fluid in terms of temperature and solid volume fraction is the greatest challenge which many scientists have faced in their studies on nanofluids. It has been showed that increasing of thermal conductivity of Al2O3/water would increase heat transfer causing wall temperature reduction [1–3]. Viscosity of Al2O3 nanoparticles dispersed in ethyleneGlycol is increased as a result of solid volume fraction increment, on the other hand increasing of temperature would cause viscosity reduction. Relative viscosity in a constant solid volume fraction is independent of temperature; also viscosity at a constant temperature is independent of solid volume fraction [4]. Viscosity of turbine lubricant is not remarkably affected by dispersion of Al2O3 nanoparticles, because heat transfer improvement is less than the reverse effects on pressure drop induced by nanoparticles' presence [5]. In some researches, experimental correlations are proposed bywhich viscosity can bepredicted in
at Esfe).
6
terms of temperature, size of nanoparticles and solid volume fraction [6, 7]. Examples of mathematical models which are proposed for the purpose of prediction viscosity of nanofluids are listed in Table 1.
It has been observed in some researches that thermal conductivity of nanofluids containing multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) linearly changes versus solid volume fraction variations. Also electrical conductivity, density and viscosity of nanofluids in presence of muftiwalled carbon nanotubes is significantly increased [22]. Thermophysical characteristics of nanofluids including viscosity and thermal conductivity depend on size of nanoparticles as well as solid volume fraction. Thermal conductivity and dynamic viscosity of nanofluids would be increased as a result of solid volume fraction increment. Moreover with decreased size of nanoparticles, thermal conductivity is enhanced but dynamic viscosity would be decreased [23–25]. Some of the studies that have been conducted on nanofluids containing Al2O3 are summarized in Table 2.
There are many papers in literature about measurement of thermophysical properties of different nanofluids [35–41] but in the present study, Al2O3-MWCNT (65%–35%)/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant is evaluated in terms of rheological behavior for the first time. The main objective of this article is practical applications of the nano-lubricant in car engines. Viscosity of the hybrid nano-lubricant was measured at solid volume fractions of 0% up to 1% and at temperatures
Nanoparticle Base fluid
Al2O3 Water Al2O3 & TiO2 Water MWCNT Water-ethylene glycol Al2O3 Glycerol Al2O3 90% ethylene glycol and 10% water Al2O3 gear oil (SAE EP-90) Al2O3 TiO2 Methanol Al2O3, CuO, SiO2, TiO2, and ZnO Water propylene glycol Al2O3 TiO2 Distilled water Al2O3 TiO2 Oil Al2O3 Ethylene glycol
Al2O3 nanoparticles were usedwith the ratio of 35% to 65% respectively. Mean diameter of Al2O3 nanoparticles is 50 nm and inner and outer diameter of multi-walled carbon nanotubes are respectively 3–5 nm and 5–15 nm.
The requiredweights of nanoparticles formaking sampleswith solid volume fractions of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1%were calculated by using Eq. (1). Samples were prepared by two-step method, to do so multi-walled carbon nanotubes and Al2O3 nanoparticles were weighted and mixed in engine oil. Samples were blended for 2–3 h by a magnetic blender. Then samples were exposed to ultrasonic waves of 20 kHz produced by a 1200 W ultrasonic processor (Kimia Nano Danesh I.R. Iran) for 6–7 h. Second blending was carried out to achieve stabilized and homogenized samples of hybrid nano-lubricant. The prepared samples alongwith the base oil, MWCNT and Al2O3 nanoparticles are depicted in Fig. 1.

Dynamic viscosity of the prepared hybrid nano-lubricant samples was measured by the use of a Brookfield viscometer manufactured by Brookfield engineering laboratories (USA). Accuracy and repeatability of the viscometer were respectively ±1.0% and ±0.2%. Viscosity
Concentration Temperature Diameter nm Ref.

0.01–0.15 1–20 – [32]
0.070–0 K 235–380 15 [33]
0.01–0.08 25–80 0–10,000 [34]

1%–4% 20 °C–60 °C 20 nm [4]
measurements were conducted at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C and shear rates between 666.5 and 10,664 s−1. In order to recalibrate the viscometer, viscosity of Ethylene Glycol and glycerin at room temperature was tested by the apparatus. Viscosity measurements at each of temperatures and shear rates were repeated in order to assure of the accuracy, measurements were repeated and average data were used.
3. Result and discussion
3.1. Rheological behavior investigation
Dynamic viscosity of a fluid is a characteristic that occurswhen force is applied to the fluid, dynamic viscosity is resistance of the fluid against flowing. In fact viscosity affects momentum transfer between layers of
re base oil and the sample with 1% solid volume fraction.

the fluid. Presence of nanoparticles in fluids, enhances viscosity due to intermolecular interactions. Each fluid differently reacts to variations of shear rate, if shear rate causes shear stress to be changed linearly then the fluid is called a Newtonian fluid, on the other hand non-linear variations of shear stress versus shear rate can be seen in fluids which are called non-Newtonian fluids. Power law equation is the governing equation of non-Newtonian fluids and it is defined as below:
τ ¼ m _γn ð2Þ
Apparent viscosity or so called effective viscosity is calculated by Eq. (3).
μ ¼ m _γn−1 ð3Þ
In Eqs. (2) and (3), μ represents the apparent viscosity, n is the power law index, m is the consistency index, τ is shear stress and _γ stands for shear rate.
Shear stress logarithmic equilibrium is presented in Eq. (4); nanolubricant's behavior is determined by the indexes of this equation.

sections.heading: Ln τð Þ ¼ Ln mð Þ þ nLn _γð Þ ð4Þ
sections.text:
Diagrams of shear stress of the samples with 0% and 1% solid volume fraction in various temperatures and shear rates are depicted in Fig. 2. Regarding these diagrams, all of the curves follow Eq. (4). It can be concluded that the pure 5w50 engine oil as well as Al2O3-MWCNT (65%– 35%)/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant samples are all non-Newtonian fluids. Power law and consistency indexes of all samples are listed in Tables 3 and 4.
Regarding Table 4, all of power law indexes are b1, this implies that the pure base oil and hybrid nano-lubricant exhibit shear thinning or pseudoplastic behavior. The most significant non-Newtonian behavior is observed for the sample with 1% solid volume fraction at the temperature of 5 °C, power law index at this point is 0.8532.
Variations of power law and consistency indexes are depicted in diagrams of Figs. 3 and 4.With regard to these diagrams consistency index is increased as a result of increasing solid volume fraction of the hybrid nano-lubricant. This phenomenon becomes more sensible when temperature is decreased. For instance, increasing of solid volume fraction

at the temperature of 55 °C results in variation of consistency index by 0.0287 while at the temperature of 5 °C, the difference between the maximum and minimum consistency indexes is 0.9091. The cause of this phenomenon is induced by formation of nano-clusters in the base fluid which enhance viscosity. These nano-clusters are formed due to Van der Waals force between the fluid's molecules. Van der Waals force is the main cause of random movement of the fluid's particles which subsequently results in Brownian movements of the dispersed nanoparticles.
In Fig. 4, diagram of power law index versus solid volume fraction at various temperatures is depicted. The general trend of power law index is that it is initially increased as a result of solid volume fraction increment but then it is reduced, this can be seenmore clearly at low temperatures. In fact it was observed that in samples with high solid volume fractions, nano-lubricant is more prone to be non-Newtonian.
The effects of temperature on consistency and power law indexes of hybrid nano-lubricant sample with 1% solid volume fraction are depicted in Fig. 5. According to this diagram, consistency index is drastically reduced as a result of temperature increment. The difference
Fig. 7. Margin of deviations for the proposed correlation.
between the consistency indexes at the temperatures of 5 °C and 55 °C is nearly 1.9. On the other hand, power law index is slightly increased as a result of temperature increment, this is more sensible at temperatures of 25 °C up to 35 °C. This increasing trend signifies that the nano-lubricant is prone to be Newtonian, though still it remained non-Newtonian.
3.2. Proposed correlation
For the purpose of approximating dynamic viscosity of Al2O3MWCNT (65%–35%)/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant, Einstein [8] and Brinkman [10] theoretical models were utilized. In Fig. 6, the outputs of the two theoretical models are compared to the experimental measurements.
According to Fig. 6, outputs of the theoreticalmodels remarkably deviate from the experimental measurements. A new correlation is proposed in terms of temperature and solid volume fraction by the use of measured data, it is presented as Eq. (5).
μnf ¼ −744:8þ 1806φ0:01382
T0:2 ð5Þ
Where φ represents solid volume fraction of the hybrid nano-lubricant, T is temperature and nf subscript stands for nanofluid. R-squared of the proposed correlation is 0.9923. The correlation is capable of predicting dynamic viscosity of Al2O3-MWCNT (65%–35%)/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant samples with 0.05% up to 1% solid volume fractions at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C. Outputs of the new correlation are depicted in Fig. 7 in ordered to be compared to the experimental data. With regard to this Figure, dynamic viscosity of the hybrid nanolubricant is desirably predicted by the new correlation. The deviations of the predicted viscosities to the experimental values are all b300 mPa.s, this represents an acceptable error.
4. Conclusion
In this article, rheological behavior of Al2O3-MWCNT (65%–35%)/ 5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant affected by temperature, solid volume fraction and shear rate was studied. Al2O3 nanoparticles with 50 nm diameter and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with inner diameter of 3–5 nm and outer diameter of 5–15 nm were dispersed in 5w50 engine oil. Dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant samples with solid volume fractions of 0% up to 1% were experimentally measured at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C. The results revealed that the base oil and the hybrid nano-lubricant are non-Newtonian. As a result of temperature increment, consistency index was decreased while power law index was increased, this signifies that at higher temperatures non-Newtonian behavior of the hybrid nano-lubricant is decreased. In order to predict dynamic viscosity of the hybrid nanolubricant, a new correlation in terms of temperature and solid volume fraction was proposed. The correlation has predicted dynamic viscosity of the hybrid nano-lubricant with R-squared of 0.9923.

referenceMentions.context: Relative viscosity in a constant solid volume fraction is independent of temperature; also viscosity at a constant temperature is independent of solid volume fraction [4].

metadata.abstractText: Available online xxxx In the present study, rheological behavior of Al2O3-MWCNT (65%–35%)/5W50 hybrid nano-lubricant is experimentally evaluated with the aim of facilitating its applications in automotive industry. Aluminum oxide (Al2O3) nanoparticles with the mean diameter of 50 nm along with multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with inner diameter of 3–5 nmand outer diameter of 5–15nmwere used as nano-dispersants. Dynamic viscosity of samples of hybrid nano-lubricant composed out of 0% up to 1% solid volume fractionwasmeasured at temperatures between 5 and 55 °C and shear rates between 666.5 and 10,664 s. As a result it was revealed that the hybrid nano-lubricant is a non-Newtonian fluid, also power law index signified shear thinning (pseudoplastic) behavior of the fluid. It was observed that increasing of solid volume fraction aggravates non-Newtonian behavior of the nano-lubricant; on the contrary, temperature increment had the reverse effect. For the purpose of forecasting viscosity of the hybrid nano-lubricant, a new correlation is proposed which is based on temperature and solid volume fraction. R-squared of the correlation outputs is 0.9923, thismeans that the correlation is capable of modeling viscosity behavior of the hybrid nano-lubricant. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
